summary: This document is an email chain from November 2020 between the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) and attorneys Gloria Allred and Mariann Wang regarding a planned in-person briefing for victims of Jeffrey Epstein in Miami. The DOJ declines to provide remote access due to COVID-19 restrictions, prompting discussion about logistical challenges for victims located internationally and across the U.S.

events.title: DOJ Victim Briefing in Miami
events.description: A meeting scheduled by the U.S. Department of Justice in Miami to brief victims of Jeffrey Epstein. The DOJ insisted on in-person attendance despite COVID-19, citing restrictions on providing remote links.

keyFacts: In November 2020, the DOJ planned an in-person briefing in Miami for Epstein victims but refused to provide remote access via phone or Zoom due to COVID-19 restrictions and logistical challenges.
Attorney Gloria Allred advocated for remote alternatives, noting that requiring victims to fly to Miami during the pandemic was unreasonable and potentially upsetting.
Allred's law firm represented Epstein victims located in multiple U.S. states and internationally, including in Norway, the UK, and Russia.
The email chain reveals coordination issues, with the DOJ seeking RSVPs and client locations while victims were hesitant or unable to attend in person.
